post.body: I created a site to test my experimental script of downloading big files (currently 5MB). Could anyone have a look and test it out? http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/
I added some videos and posters to my **ZeroBlog Lab** site for testing big file streaming.

Currently, ZeroNet saves all files into the `data` folder, which is why people don't like big sites. `:(`

If we can move the big file to a place rich in space while still keeping ZeroNet seeding it, we will be more pleased to stream big files from the ZeroNet. `:)` @nofish

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/
Firefox users can now play the video when it is still being downloaded.
The player will show up when the first 1/5 of the progress bar has been filled.

[1] Please click on the links labelled **Stream** if you would like to test this feature. I was not realized that the first two videos are not streaming friendly.

[2] Firefox is recommended :)

While I am optimizing the MP4 fragmenting program, I rearranged `ui.js` and published the rearranged version [on my site](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/js/ui.js). Hopefully people who would like to read my code can understand it more easily.

Big sites take so long to sign...

Perhaps I can:
- Use separate `content.json` files.
- Be patient.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V
Now the big file streaming script is checking the hash of the big, reassembled file in a Web Worker.

I tested it against a 200MB file. When the hash of the big file was being checked, the web page still responded to scrolling and video seeking.

Though it is not necessary to check the hash of the reassembled file, I worked out a way to use Web Workers in ZeroNet's `iframe` without running into any cross origin errors.

If a cross origin error causes `new Worker("async-hash.js");` and `importScripts('asmcrypto.js');` to fail, putting the content of the script into a `blob:` URL can bypass this error.

The MP4 multiplexer, written completely in JavaScript, is finally live on my website!

If you are using Firefox, you can **play any video on that page as you are buffering it**.

You can't believe the amount of code I wrote.

I am going to write some docs on my JavaScript projects, the file downloading script and the MP4 multiplexer. However, they do not have very beautiful **names**. Any suggestions on how they should be called?

    ZeroChunks     mp4fragment.js
    ZeroBytes      mp4mux.js
    ZeroBigFile    ZeroMux

I cannot see some people's posts. Do I need to seed all ZeroMe hubs?
@nofish: As ZeroMe gets bigger, it may need a personal blacklist feature.

##How to block a person on ZeroMe
1. Find the public key of the person you want to block.
2. Find the folder named after that public key in the hub folder.
3. Go into that person's folder and look at `data.json`. Make sure that person is the right person you want to block.
4. Delete all his or her files, including `content.json`. Then immediately make a `content.json` **folder** at the same place to prevent that file from showing up again.
5. You cannot see that person's posts and comments anymore.

        data/users/14fdwxPt83nTw5vFaXTCR7KQkAxkXuGbAR/content.json

    14fdwxPt83nTw5vFaXTCR7KQkAxkXuGbAR - doom1b@zeroid.bit

[These instructions](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1RedkCkVaXuVXrqCMpoXQS29bwaqsuFdL/1LxkfGxtWhktAJ5WJ9ZnKxksTSH37qm8cC/1474862332) on blocking users are not a long-term solution, as an empty `content.json` folder is not what ZeroNet expects. It prevents ZeroNet from updating the site. Even after the site owner banned the spammer, ZeroNet cannot update these changes.

[Take a peek](/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/img/redirect.html?player.png) at what I am working on.
##### If link doesn't work, try copying and pasting URL.
ZeroMux and docs will be updated tomorrow. Stay tuned!

I fixed  an async hash calculating bug in [ZeroMux](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/). Now, as long as you put the files of ZeroMux in the same folder, `download.js` will always find the files it needs.

Despite its name, [ZeroMux](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/) is also a general purpose file downloader and can handle files other than MP4. Read the documentation [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/).

Several variables are declared as global by mistake, causing potential name conflicts. Now this bug is fixed.

[ZeroMux Demos](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/) and [Documentation](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/)

I am writing a new page of documentation for ZeroMux. It is on working with fragmented data streams.

```
What we want:
[################                       ]     
0%                                      100%

What we have:
[########  #### #    #  ##       #    # ]
0%                                      100%

```
It seems that someone thought I was the developer of ZeroNet. =) I am not! I am the developer of a program that is hosted on ZeroNet.

Remember to support [ZeroMux](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/) and [aurora.js](https://github.com/audiocogs/aurora.js/). Remember to seed, and enjoy the song!

###雪ノ下雪乃(CV.早見沙織) 由比ヶ浜結衣(CV.東山奈央)
###Everyday World

I realized that, [ZeroMux](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/) is too difficult to use for people who want to share files but don't know much programming. To make ZeroMux simpler, I came up with some ideas to be implemented:

- Create a link to download all necessary tools rather than telling people to find the site folder.
- Write a Python program to help people split files and configure ZeroMux without having to write a line of code.
- Create a permanent link for every big file.

##Dealing with spammers
If you run a website on ZeroNet, please ban these 3 ZeroMe spammers:
```
"meylody@zeroid.bit": false,
"plac@zeroid.bit": false,
"thejumono@zeroid.bit": false
```

Add them to `data/users/content.json` and sign this file. [Example](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/img/redirect.html?../data/users/content.json)

I put together some very interesting ideas on how to deal with spammers in a distributed network. Many of them are still ideas:

- **Proof of Work:** A hard problem takes a few seconds to solve.
- **Decentralized CAPTCHA:** Everyone generates a CAPTCHA according to the rule of this game.
- **Proof of Contribution:** Want to seed? Want to store? Want to donate?
- **Centralized Approval:** An imperial order by the site moderators.

To proof yourself in a distributed network, you have to give out some information that is not only unique to your state but also easy for everyone to check.

Things to check:
1. The peer is following the common rules.
2. The peer has given out information that can reliably imply what we want it to have.

Example: Decentralized CAPTCHA
1. The peer is generating legit CAPTCHAs. It is not generating random, illegible noises. It is not reusing old CAPTCHAs.
2. Solving the CAPTCHA using a computer is hard, but checking the answer is easy. In this way, giving out the answer implies that a real human being, rather than spammer bots, is writing a post. Everyone can effectively conclude that, because it is easy to check the validity of an answer.

Problem with a Decentralized CAPTCHA idea on ZeroTalk:
1. There is no easy way to check if a CAPTCHA is legit.

An Open Question to Every ZeroNet Contributor

## How to maintain a reasonable balance between storage availability and data availability, using algorithms?

(Updated)

When I read the homepage of bit.no.com, the ZeroNet proxy, I noticed that the proxy found more peers than my own ZeroNet client did. When I clicked on my ZeroMux website to see the peers bit.no.com found, I saw many points that I could not find on my own map. I believe that those extra points were computers that were no longer reachable. (Correction: peer list is updated every 1~4 hours)

Several days ago, the owner of https://onlyzero.net/ , a ZeroNet proxy, received a takedown complaint from a Hong Kong company, forcing the site owner to take down a software cracking site hosted on the proxy. This complaint is the first takedown complaint that makes us be aware of peer reliability in ZeroNet.

ZeroNet chooses which optional file to recycle according to the number of peers the file has. ZeroNet may have included the peers that are "dead," unreachable and very slow, or have other incorrect assumptions on peer reliability. To make a more accurate calculation, ZeroNet's corresponding algorithm should apply a weight to every peer.

### How to define the weight?
Concerns:
- We cannot rely on peers that are "dead," slow and unlikely to **contribute**.
- We cannot rely too much on **major seeders**. When someone tries to take down certain content, he or she will take down the major seeders first.

Aspects to take in, including but not limited to:
- **Connectivity:** the "ping" value of a peer __(but adds to data transfer)__; the speed a peer __(but has insufficient data)__; the ratio of the number of successful connections to the number of all connections made __(requires bigger sample size)__.
- **Contribution:** recent contributions of a peer, observed by ZeroNet itself. __(but varies with respect to network environment)__.

Mathematical Fairness:
- Since we cannot rely too much on major seeders, the weight should not be greater than 1. This cut off avoids over-evaluating big seeding peers.
- Since ZeroNet evaluates data availability based on its observation of its own network environment, ZeroNet may run into some false positives. We should also find a way to cross validate evaluations. (Hard)

### Viability
The weight defined above requires a lot of information, and it is costly to gather all these information only to calculate weights. Perhaps we can take a more heuristic approach, at the beginning, assuming all peers has a weight of 0.9, and changing the weight value when latest information is available.

This algorithm may be too strict and paranoid, but this algorithm can be helpful when there are disruptions targeting the ZeroNetwork going on.

comment.body: @Nofish: I agree. Using `_top` works best in most browsers.
It works.
You can label files as "optional files", so they do take space but do not count as site size.

@Sirenyc: There is an example on [ReadTheDocs](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#optional) and an example on my site: 
`"optional": "(big/files/.*dat)"`
It is a Regular Expression
You can use `"optional": "(big/files/.*jpg)"`

According to @nofish, big file support is planned. [Here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/7#issuecomment-246185262) is the issue #7 on big file support. Here is the [pull request](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/521) on big file support. These are all I know about big file support.
On the other hand, I want to keep file loading in browser, I don't want to do video conversion by hand, and I don't know how to modify the code of ZeroNet, so I made my own file loading script. My code is different and separate.
There is a like button, but I believe adding a "dislike" button is wasting data.
Exploiting programs in 3 billion devices.

@Binero: I know. Don't upload personal files onto ZeroNet. If you want to share files privately, encrypt them first.
@Zanity: Storing real files on the server requires much more energy than storing torrents.
@Jro: On my own ZeroNet client, Nofish's Blog seems to be not updated.
Just an advice, can the interpolation algorithm for displaying thumbnails be changed to make the image show clear pixels with sharp edges?
@Nofish: It works. The Db takes a long time to build.

@Titan: No :) This is intended to be a public file sharing software. If you want to share files privately, encrypt it with 7Zip first, and tell only the people you want about the password.

By the way, this is also true when you are using ~~traditional~~ centralized file sharing services.
